Furthermore, there is a problem, and that is a geological and, if you like, a climate situation.
The Mississippi River delta sinks.
Why?
Because all sediments compact and, therefore, they take everything with them down as they age.
And New Orleans is built on this delta, so it sinks.
Now normally, the river would replenish this deficit of sediments by pouring, during flooding times, new sediments on it.

But since 1920, we have mandated the US Army Corps of Engineer to build levees to protect the city, but also to keep the river in its bed, which means we send all those sediments out into the Gulf, far from that area.
Therefore, there is no equilibrium anywhere of this nature.
The second natural process that we have to keep in mind is sea level is rising, and we all contribute to that by driving cars, having lights on and all the rest of it, so greenhouse gases.
Currently, the rate is about three feet per century that these combined effects result into.
A hundred years from now, this will have risen to about five feet per century.
